Geometries associated with relative stabilities, infrared spectra, and energy gaps of the slightly deformed (Ge6B6)n (n¼ 2e10) nanocages are systematically investigated applying density functional theory. Particularly, the relative stabilities in terms of the calculated averaged atomic binding energies and fragmentation energies show that (GeB)36 cage has enhanced stability over other nanoclusters. Interestingly, (Ge6B6)n nanocages prefer to the sphere-like geometries with large inner hollow spaces. Moreover, the calculated energy gaps of (Ge6B6)n nanocages are decreased generally and the wavelengths of absorption spectra in sphere-like (Ge6B6)n clusters are elongated with the increased size of (Ge6B6)n nanocages. The quantum confinement effect indirectly is revealed; furthermore, the nanosized (GeB)36-60 cages have a very stronger capacity for solar energy absorption or conversion due to narrow energy gaps and large DOS near LUMO and HOMO levels. Additionally, germanium atoms transfer electronic charges to their surrounding boron atoms, charge-transfers between Ge and B enhance stabilities of the nanocages. SH2 gas is sensitive to GeB cage and can be used to removal SH2 from air.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Bubble-like nanoclusters exhibit unique geometrical and electronic properties due to the strong influence of the higher number of surface atoms and corresponding electronic effects [1e7]. Evidently, the stable and size-specific sphere-like GeB nanocluster semiconductors are a growing interesting research field because of its many promising technological and fundamental practical applications in the optical and electronic devices in that the electronic, magnetic, optical, physical and chemical properties of sphere-like nanoclusters are found to vary with their sizes and compositions. Furthermore, nanoclusters can be used as the building blocks for cluster assembled nanomaterials and generate the useful semiconductor devices, Pure germanium clusters are studied theoretically and are shown unsuitable for the building blocks in that they are chemically reactive because of the existence of dangling bonds. The boron clusters show various geometrical forms, a number of cage, spherical, and fullerene shapes are identified to have several distinct growth patterns. Boron-doped germanium nanoclusters, consequently, may interact with

germanium atoms to form more stable cage-like geometries. Development of new germanium based nanomaterials with tunable new electronic properties, the germanium nanoclusters with boron and transition metal impurities have been studied extensively by experimental and computational methods [7e14]. The materials composed of germanium-boron matrices is developed as a very important research area within the semiconductor technology fields, which can be applied in the construction of high performance electronic, optical, and bipolar transistor devices. Such technologically relevant GeB materials which are usually generated by the slow diffusion of the added boron atoms into germanium at high temperature is apparently favored. The fabrication of the n-type boron doped Ge energy cell materials with the formation of high-quality and high-efficiency structures is investigated and will be achieved by local boron impurity doping technical method, photovoltaic characteristics contribute to the improvement of solar cell efficiency with low cost, an efficient, and reproducible manner simultaneously as compared with other materials. Furthermore, the obtained important materials in semiconductor technology with boron atoms being used as p-type dopant of germanium materials are employed in devices for highspeed bipolar transistors [8]. A lots of experimental studies are preformed on the obtainable alternative materials

characterization by boron implantation and diffusion in germanium atoms [8e10].
In spite of their importance of GeB materials in the electronic and optical industry, the geometrical and electronic characterization as well as the description of the chemical bondings of those GeB species are very interesting and the accurate investigations are still a challenge until now, from my point of view there are no systematical computational studies on the insertion of boron into germanium-based matrices.
The geometries and electronic properties of (Ge6B6)n (n¼ 2e10) nanocages have not been fully understood experimentally and theoretically because of the experimental challenges to exactly identify them. In addition, as the number of isomers increases rapidly with cluster size, it is very difficult to determine the global minimum simply according to the calculated energies of the isomers without reference to experimental or previous theoretical information. Fortunately, previous theoretical results on InN, CdS, and ZnO are provided [2,6,15]. This investigation provides the description of the geometrical and electronic properties of nanocages formed by boron bonded to Ge elements using established density functional methods. Thus, the systematic calculations have been performed applying the density functional methodology to germanium borides. Thus, the main goals of this study are focusing on predictions of the new geometries and their stabilities, and electronic properties of (Ge6B6)n (n¼ 2e10) nanoclusters theoretically.

sections.heading: 2. Computational details
sections.text:
The use of an adequate all-electron basis sets for Gewouldmake the geometry optimizations of the larger ones among the (Ge6B6)n nanoclusters considered here a prohibitively time-consuming effort. The effective electron core potentials (ECP) approach can surmount this difficulty [16] through the application of the effective core potential (ECP) method to treat inner shell electrons and the density functional theory (DFT) treatment of the exchange and correlation terms, as only the valence electrons are explicitly included in our all calculations [16]. It has been shown that the double zeta LanL2DZ ECP basis set is capable of generating results of very satisfactory quality for nanosized (Ge6B6)n systems. Here, we demonstrate that the combination of density functional theory (DFT) methods with ECP also can provide an accurate and reliable approach to study the properties of the (Ge6B6)n systems.
All geometries are optimized at the level of the gradient corrected PBE (Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof) exchange-correlation functional [17,18] within the Kohn-Sham density functional theory framework as implemented in the Gaussian 09 code [19]. The LanL2DZ basis sets are used for boron and germanium atoms in all calculations. The test cases of Ge2 and GeB dimers are calculated by the selected methods, our calculated GeeB bond length in GeB dimer is 2.037 Å with 4 P , which agrees well with the theoretical
value of 1.999 Å calculated at MRCI-CASSCF/aug-cc-pV5Z-DK level [12]. Our calculated GeeGe bond length for singlet Ge2 dimer is 2.354 Å, which agrees with the previous reported value of 2.53 Å [7]. Consequently, the selected PBE-GGAmethods used in this study are accurate and reasonable enough to describe the geometrical and electronic properties of (Ge6B6)n nanoclusters.
Present geometrical optimizations of (Ge6B6)n nanoclusters are systematically carried out for all designed isomers, and then followed by the evaluation of their harmonic vibrational frequencies in order to attest the clusters’ stabilities and make sure that all optimized geometries are stable. All calculations are carried out at 298.15 K under 1 atm. In addition, the total energy includes zeropoint vibrational energy (ZPVE).

sections.heading: 3.1. Geometries and stabilities
sections.text:
Ge12B12 fullerene-like cluster is studied and calculated at the PBE-GGA level with LanL2DZ basis sets (Fig. 1) [20] and the most essential result of the cluster is summarized in Table 1. The Ge12B12 cluster is regarded as the smaller volume cluster obeying the law of isolated four-membered rings. It is found that the remarkably Ge12B12, which possesses a high Th point-group symmetry with zero dipole moment, is highly stable with a sphere-like geometry with eight six-membered rings and six isolated four-membered rings. It is particularly interesting phenomena that the most stable Ge12B12 cage has two types of GeeB bonds [2]. As for the two types of GeeB bonds, a longer GeeB bond (2.09 Å) connects two neighboring four-membered rings and a shorter one (2.06 Å) in four-membered rings, which are in good agreement with the reported theoretical values [11]. The energy gap between the highest occupied molecular orbital and the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital for Ge12B12 is 1.79 eV, indicating that it has a narrow-band semiconducting property and the sphere-like Ge12B12 geometry is more energetically favorable isomer. The optimized (GeB)12 cage with boron and Ge atoms of sp3 hybridization exhibits that all Ge and boron atoms are threefold coordinated with electron charges being transferred to boron atoms from Ge atoms. The high symmetry and big HOMOeLUMO gap reflect that sphere-like Ge12B12 cluster can be seen as the building blocks used for synthesizing promising cluster-assembled nanomaterials with novel physical and chemical properties used for real applications.
A cage-like (GeB)18 geometry is selected as an initial structure, unfortunately, its final optimized geometry presents as a cubic-like form, reflecting that the sphere-like geometry is unfavorable one while the cubic-like geometry is a favorable structure. This finding is completely different from that of (InN)18 cages [2]. On the basis of the calculated data summarized in Table 1, the deformed cubic like (GeB)18 nanocage is obviously the most stable one with calculated dipole moment being 0.02 Debye. As far as (GeB)24 nanocluster with S4 symmetry is concerned (Fig. 1), the bubble (GeB)24 nanocage having six four-membered squares and twelve six-membered rings is considered and optimized as a stable geometry. Interestingly, the (GeB)24 nanocluster with zero dipole moment can be described as two semisphere (GeB)12 cages being combined together in geometrical forms.
Bubble-like (GeB)30 nanocluster with C1 symmetry is deviated to higher symmetry slightly, which can be reflected from the calculated zero dipolemoment listed in Table 1. As can be seen from the optimized geometry shown in Fig. 1, the sphere-like (GeB)30 nanocluster completely differs from sphere-like nitrogen or carbon analogues. As shown in Fig. 1, it is apparent that this nanocage is composed of eight squares and sixteen hexagons along with six octagons. The calculated GeeB bond lengths of the stable (GeB)30 nanocage are 2.01e2.09 Å and 2.05e2.08 for six-member hexagons and four-member squares, respectively; together with the orbitals of Ge atoms and boron atoms exhibiting sp3 hybridization character after electron charges transfer from Ge atoms to their neighboring boron atoms. In addition, electronic properties of this sphere-like nanocage can be changed by encapsulating clusters, molecules, and atoms into its inner hollow sphere; especially, because of the existed octagons, water molecule can be encapsulated in to the inner sphere. The application of this advantage of (GeB)30 nanocage can be extended in new semiconductor or magnetic materials with expected new properties.
According to the calculated data of dipole moment (1.20 Debye) listed in Table 1, it is obvious that nanosized C1 (GeB)36 cage is slightly deformed from higher Td point-group symmetry.

Particularly, the (GeB)36 nanocluster shows structural rigidity similar to that of its (InN)36 counterparts [2], the stable C1 (GeB)36 cage being composed of 24 hexagons and 6 squares can be described as six hemispheres of Ge24B24 nanocage. Furthermore, (GeB)36 nanocluster satisfies with stable 18-electron rule, normally, this nanocage should be the magic number of the relative stability.
As far as (GeB)42 nanocages is concerned, (GeB)42(a) nanocage, which is described as a (GeB)6 hexagonal prism being encapsulated into a stable sphere-like (GeB)36 nanocluster, is an encapsulated nanocage. Its electronic properties are actually different from those of small size (Ge6B6)n (n¼ 2e6) nanocages because of the static interactions between (GeB)6 and (GeB)36 units. The encapsulated (GeB)6 hexagonal prism can enhance the stability of (GeB)42(b) nanocage. In addition, a purely novel sphere-like (GeB)42 nanocage is optimized to be a stable geometry, this geometry is different from those of (InN)42 and (ZnO)42 [2,15]. Although, the averaged atomic binding energy of former is slightly bigger than that of the later, this purely sphere-like (GeB)42(a) nanocage without encapsulation is discussed in following sections.
In order to avoid homobonding in fullerene-like nanosized (GeB)48 cage, C1 (GeB)48 being composed of 34 hexagons and 6 squares has a slightly deformed Ci group symmetry, which is reflected from our calculated value of dipole moment. On the basis of the optimized geometry of (GeB)48 nanocage shown in Fig. 1, this cage is described as six hemispheres of (BGe)12 cage (Fig. 1), which exterior is similar to that of (GeB)36 nanocage mentioned above. In addition, the hollow C1 (GeB)48 nanocage possesses a stronger capability to host various small clusters and atoms.
The optimized sphere-like (GeB)54 nanocluster is an irregular nanocage, which has lower C1 symmetry. As can be seen from calculated results in Table 1, it is obvious that the dipole moment of (GeB)54 nanocluster is the biggest one (3.18 Debye) and the lowest frequency (13.4 cm 1) is smaller than those of the small-size nanocages, reflecting that (GeB)54 geometry is deviated to the global form with a bigger dipole moment as compared with those of other nanocages.
The new (GeB)60 nanocluster is optimized as a stable sphere-like geometry with six squares being protruded out. Obviously, the stable geometry is completely different from that of encapsulated (ZnO)60 nanocage [15] and is revealed for the first time. Furthermore, such a sphere-like nanosized (GeB)60 cluster slightly deviates to the higher D3h symmetry in geometry. The geometry can be seen as a triangular prism in form. Actually, the calculated energy gap of sphere-like nanosized (GeB)60 cluster is smaller as compared with its neighboring GeB nanocage, indicating that the effective HOMO and LUMO band gap of nanosized sphere-like (GeB)60 cluster is narrow, and more and more solar light with the long wavelength ranges is effectively harvested, consequentially, the solar light adsorption efficiency for large (GeB)6n nanocage is undoubtedly
Please cite this article as: R.-N. Zhao et al., A density functional study on fullerene-like BGe nanomaterials, Journal of Alloys and Compounds, http
increased. Moreover, the solar light absorption spectra ranges of (GeB)6n nanocage undergo a very important red shift as the size being increased, in other words, the solar light absorption spectra for (GeB)6n nanocage vary from solar light short wavelength to solar light long wave length with the extended size, this finding agrees well with the previous experimental observation [21e23]. In addition, our predicted densities of states (DOSs) of the large size (GeB)60 nanocluster is actually higher in comparison with those of the small size (Ge6B6)n (n¼ 2e10) nanocages, therefore, the higher density of states of large size (GeB)60 cluster indicates that more and more photo excitation are generated from energy levels near HOMO orbital to higher energy levels; Thus, the solar light absorption intensities for the large size nanocages are enhanced greatly along with the increased efficiency of photon to current storage or conversion. The (GeB)60 nanocage with bigger density of states (DOS) has stronger capacity for solar energy storage or conversion, this finding provides a new application of nanomaterials in solar energy conversion or storage.

sections.heading: 3.2. Relative stability
sections.text:

The total energies of B, Ge, and Ge6B6 units are 24.496976, 3.686922, and 171.199767 Hartree, respectively. The calculated averaged atomic binding energies and fragmentation energies for different-sized sphere-like (Ge6B6)n nanoclusters are tabulated in Table 1 and shown in respective Fig. 2a and Fig. 2b.
In light of the calculated averaged atomic binding energy curve shown in Fig. 2a, it is obviously exhibited that the averaged atomic binding energies of the most stable sphere-like (Ge6B6)n (n¼ 2e10) nanoclusters are increased generally as the size being extended. Three distinct peaks localized at the calculated averaged atomic binding energy curve give evidences the corresponding three distinguished (GeB)24, (GeB)36, and (GeB)54 nanocages have larger averaged atomic binding energy Eb(n) than their neighboring nanosized sphere-like GeB clusters, showing these three stable bubble-like nanoclusters have stronger relative stabilities in

As can be seen from Fig. 2a, the bubble-like (GeB)30, on the contrary, has apparently lower averaged atomic binding energy and lower relative stability than its neighboring nanocages (1< n< 11). In order to demonstrate our calculated results of relative stabilities of spherelike (Ge6B6)n (n¼ 2e10) nanoclusters, the calculated fragmentation energy (D(n,n-1)) are the important physical quantities in which the relative stability in terms of the calculated averaged atomic binding energy above can be certificated and the relative stability of the sphere-like (Ge6B6)n (n¼ 2e10) nanoclusters can be more accurately described.
The sized dependence D(n,n-1) of nanosized (Ge6B6)n (n¼ 2e10) sphere-like clusters is plotted in Fig. 2b curve. The remarkable magic numbers of stabilities of (Ge6B6)n (n¼ 2e10) nanoclusters are found, which are assigned to be n¼ 3, 6, and 9. Interestingly, the n¼ 6 is assigned to be the maximum magic number of the relative stability; particularly, (GeB)36 nanocage is the most stable geometry of all the bubble-like (Ge6B6)n (n¼ 2e10) nanoclusters. This new finding of the maximum magic number is obviously the same as that of our calculated averaged atomic binding energy above. Although the (GeB)36 nanocage is the most

sections.heading: 3.3. HOMO-LUMO gaps
sections.text:
The energy gaps between highest occupied molecular orbital level (HOMO) and lowest unoccupied molecular orbital level (LUMO) for the most stable (Ge6B6)n (n¼ 2e10) nanocages are calculated and shown in Fig. 3 and summarized in Table 1. According to energy gap (HOMO-LUMO) values of (Ge6B6)n nanocages, all of the large size (Ge6B6)n nanocages are outstanding narrow band semiconductors. As seen from calculated results shown in Fig. 3 and listed in Table 1, our calculated energy gap values for (Ge6B6)n (n¼ 2e10) nanocages are decreased apparently with increased size of (Ge6B6)n (n¼ 2e10) nanocages. Interestingly, the small size (GeB)12 cluster with the largest energy gap, which can be used as an assembled building block, can form the assemble width-band gap semiconductor nanomaterials with new physical and chemical properties, However, the other nanosized (Ge6B6)n (n¼ 3e10) cages are narrow-band semiconductor nanomaterials, which are completely different from that of small size (GeB)12 cage. Obviously, the calculated energy gap values of bubble-like (Ge6B6)n (n¼ 2e10) nanocages have shown a generally trend that it gradually decreases with the increased sphere-like (Ge6B6)n (n¼ 2e10) nanocluster’s size. Therefore, the Ge and B surface atoms in large size (Ge6B6)n (n¼ 2e10) nanocages possess the distinct metallic characters, indicating electrons in (Ge6B6)n (n¼ 2e10) nanocages move more freely on the nanosized (Ge6B6)n (n¼ 2e10) surfaces when the size of nanosized (Ge6B6)n (n¼ 2e10) cages is increased. Furthermore, the absorption spectra of (Ge6B6)n (n¼ 2e10) nanocages are changed, and varying to long wavelength from short wavelength as the extended sphere-like (Ge6B6)n (n¼ 2e10) size, this finding reflects that the wavelength range of the light absorption in spherelike (GeB)60 nanocluster is significantly widened, moreover, the quantum-size effect is indirectly revealed based upon this finding. Obviously, (GeB)60 has the smallest energy gap.

In addition, our calculated LUMO and HOMO energy levels at the PBE-GGA level for different size sphere-like nanoclusters are changed gradually and the corresponding DOS near LUMO and HOMO levels becomes obviously more and more large when the nanocage size is increased, reflecting that the (Ge6B6)n (n¼ 2e10) nanocages are appropriate for solar energy absorption or conversion nanomaterials because efficiency of solar energy conversion and absorption is obviously in direct proportion to the DOS near HOMO levels of GeB nanocages. According to our obtained DOS near LUMO and HOMO levels (shown in Fig. 4), photon to current conversion rate involved in the light absorption intensities, together with obtained DOS of nanocages near HOMO and LUMO levels, are increased generally when bubble-like (Ge6B6)n (n¼ 2e10) size n is gradually increased from n¼ 2 to n¼ 10.

sections.heading: 3.4. IR absorption spectra
sections.text:
The calculated infrared (IR) adsorption spectra for the (Ge6B6)n (n¼ 2e10) nanocages are shown in Fig. 6. According to the calculated IR values of (Ge6B6)n (n¼ 2e10) nanocages, two stronger peaks for (GeB)12 are shown and localized at respective 420 cm 1 causing by torsionmovement of nanocage and 605 cm 1 causing by boron movement in four-membered ring, and other weaker peaks appear in Fig. 6. As the size of nanocages is increased, a number of particular peaks are obviously exhibited that they localize at about 150e450 and 560e800 cm 1, no adsorption spectra observe at about 450e550 cm 1. Consequently, the nanosized (Ge6B6)n (n¼ 2e10) cages are good infrared adsorption nanomaterials, and can absorb specialized infrared photo-wavelengths localized at infrared regions. Undoubtedly, nanosized (Ge6B6)n (n¼ 2e10) cages are good candidates for solar energy adsorption or conversion nanomaterials and can be used for high-capacity and high-stability electrode materials.
3.5. Charge-transfer in (Ge6B6)n (n¼ 2e10) nanocages
The calculated averaged natural atomic populations of Ge atoms in (Ge6B6)n (n¼ 2e10) nanoclusters are shown in Fig. 7 and tabulated in Table 1. The electron charges in (Ge6B6)n (n¼ 2e10) nanocages are transferred toward boron atoms from their neighboring germanium atoms, furthermore, the static interactions between germanium and boron atoms obviously enhance stabilities of (Ge6B6)n (n¼ 2e10) nanocage surface. More importantly, the semiconductor properties of the (Ge6B6)n (n¼ 2e10) nanocages are slightly reduced and electron movement in nanosized (Ge6B6)n (n¼ 2e10) cage surface is more free as size of (Ge6B6)n nanocages being extended. When the size of (Ge6B6)n (n¼ 2e10) nanoclusters is gradually increased, averaged atomic natural charge-transfers are generally increased, the finding exhibits that the ionic bonds between Ge and B atoms become more and more important to stabilize the large size (Ge6B6)n nanocages, in other words, the metallic characteristic becomes more and more obvious as the size of nanocages being increased.

sections.heading: 3.6. SH2 molecule adsorbed on (Ge6B6)n surface
sections.text: On the base of the calculated results, it is easy to find that (Ge6B6)n nanocages are sensitive to SH2 molecule, thus, (Ge6B6)n nanocages can be used to remove SH2 molecule in industry or air. The absorption of SH2 molecule on the surface of (Ge6B6)n (n¼ 2 and 4) nanocages is investigated, which is shown in Fig. 6. The SH2 molecule absorption energies for Ge12B12 is 0.6 eV, for Ge36B36 are respective 0.22 and 0.31 eV.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
Optimized geometries and electronic properties of the stable nanosized (Ge6B6)n (n¼ 2e10) cages are investigated using density functional theory utilizing PBE-GGA exchange-correlation functional within the effective core potential LanL2DZ basis sets for respective Ge, B, S, and H atoms. The obtained new findings for (Ge6B6)n (n¼ 2e10) cages are summarized: Geometries of nanosized (Ge6B6)n (n¼ 2e10) cages are optimized, it is obvious that the stable geometries being composed of hexagons and squares with inner hollow spaces are the favorable and dominant forms. Furthermore, the inner hollow (Ge6B6)n (n¼ 2e10) nanocages can encapsulate small molecules or clusters to change the properties and geometries of the nanocages for special applications. The calculated fragmentation energies reveal that the particular stable bubble-like (GeB)36 cluster can be used as a new building block for a cluster-assembled nanomaterials. Averaged natural atomic populations of germanium atoms for bubble-like (Ge6B6)n (n¼ 2e10) nanocages are calculated and tabulated in Table 1. It is found that germanium atoms transfer their electronic charges to their surrounding boron atoms. Charge-transfers between Ge and B atoms in GeB nanocages can enhance their geometrical stabilities. Particularly, the calculated energy gaps for bubble-like (Ge6B6)n (n¼ 2e10) nanocages exhibit that the largest HOMO-LUMO gap in bubble-like (GeB)24 cluster leads to the distinct semiconductor characters. Furthermore, the energy gaps of nanosized bubble-like (Ge6B6)n (n¼ 2e10) clusters are decreased generally, together with the wavelength of absorption spectra for nanosized bubble-like (Ge6B6)n (n¼ 2e10) clusters being elongated, when the size of bubble-like (Ge6B6)n (n¼ 2e10) nanoclusters is increased. This phenomenon exhibits indirectly the quantum confinement effect. The metallic characters of Ge and B surface atoms in large size (Ge6B6)n (n¼ 2e10) nanocages are explored. Additionally, all sizes of bubble-like (GeB)36-60 nanocages have a very stronger capacity used for the solar energy absorption and conversion due to narrow energy gaps and large DOS near LUMO and HOMO levels of nanosized (Ge6B6)n (n¼ 2e10) cages.

metadata.abstractText: Geometries associated with relative stabilities, infrared spectra, and energy gaps of the slightly deformed (Ge6B6)n (n1⁄4 2e10) nanocages are systematically investigated applying density functional theory. Particularly, the relative stabilities in terms of the calculated averaged atomic binding energies and fragmentation energies show that (GeB)36 cage has enhanced stability over other nanoclusters. Interestingly, (Ge6B6)n nanocages prefer to the sphere-like geometries with large inner hollow spaces. Moreover, the calculated energy gaps of (Ge6B6)n nanocages are decreased generally and the wavelengths of absorption spectra in sphere-like (Ge6B6)n clusters are elongated with the increased size of (Ge6B6)n nanocages. The quantum confinement effect indirectly is revealed; furthermore, the nanosized (GeB)36-60 cages have a very stronger capacity for solar energy absorption or conversion due to narrow energy gaps and large DOS near LUMO and HOMO levels. Additionally, germanium atoms transfer electronic charges to their surrounding boron atoms, charge-transfers between Ge and B enhance stabilities of the nanocages. SH2 gas is sensitive to GeB cage and can be used to removal SH2 from air. © 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
